It's taking me longer than expected, but I'm making progress. Can I send a rough breakdown of my research soon and get some feedback?

author: sky.cactus
content: <@!194432762315407360> I could use some help figuring out the best way to write this Typed Transactions over Gossip EIP.  I'm struggling because I really want to avoid having to do a devp2p version bump every time a new transaction type is introduced, but we also need to be careful about clients starting to propagate new transaction types to peers that don't support it.

author: sky.cactus
content: One option would be to assert that a new transaction type is invalid for gossip until its fork block is reached, but tying devp2p to fork blocks is a big can of worms and doesn't actually work really (considering rollbacks and such).  We could *try* to work around some of these issues by asserting that they are valid for receiving within `n` blocks of fork block but clients **MUST** only send them after the fork block... but this feels like a bit of a hack.

author: sky.cactus
content: What I'm concerned about is that if we don't say that sending an invalid transaction type is grounds for de-peering, then we may be introducing a DoS vector where someone can just spam their peers with transaction types that the peer doesn't know about, and the peer will just keep dropping them thinking "oh, I guess this is a new type and just need an update to understand it".

author: sky.cactus
content: And if we do say that receiving an invalid transaction type is grounds for de-peering, then we have the problem of figuring out at what point in time a new transaction type goes from "invalid" to "valid".

author: sky.cactus
content: Maybe the right solution here is to de-peer anyone who sends you a transaction type you don't understand, and rely on the fact that by the time any *reasonable* client is sending out new transaction types we are *very close to a fork block* and if you aren't up to date yet then you are going to fork away from the network in a few minutes anyway so whatever.

author: sky.cactus
content: Currently: Transaction hash is `keccak256(rlp([nonce, gasPrice, gasLimit, to, value, data, v, r, s]))` right?

author: guthl_starkware
content: Interesting <@!301186049323958275>, I'm looking at the same thing. Do you know why the txHash is not accessible within the EVM?

author: Deleted User
content: I think it is actually good thing it is not accessible

author: Deleted User
content: <@!301186049323958275> I think what you are really struggling is the coupling of transaction serialisation used over devp2p being the same as the transaction serialisation used for creating TxHash in the block. If these were decoupled, then you could look at them separarely

author: Deleted User
content: if we accepted such decoupling, meaning that "what we put in devp2p message can be different from what we use to compute TxHash for the block", then it can get easier to manage

author: sky.cactus
content:
> transaction serialisation used for creating TxHash in the block
<@456226577798135808> Blocks don't have transaction hashes anywhere in them do they?

author: sky.cactus
content: The transaction root is for a merkle patricia trie where the path is `rlp(transactionIndex)` and the value is just the serialized transaction.

author: Deleted User
content: Block headers have a field "TxHash" which is a hash of Patricia tree constructed from mapping `TxIndex => Transaction serialisation`

author: Deleted User
content: Yes, that's it

author: Deleted User
content: I cannot offer you any concrete help at the moment, unfortunately, until we get some progress on the separate tx pool network

author: Deleted User
content: one of the goals of such network is to experiment with decoupling

author: sky.cactus
content: devp2p, on the other hand, has `keccak256(Transaction)` I believe?  And at the moment, the thing being hashed matches the value in the transaction merkle trie?

author: Deleted User
content: devp2p has multiple messages that contain transaction serialisation

author: sky.cactus
content:
> one of the goals of such network is to experiment with decoupling
<@456226577798135808> I'm a big fan of splitting Ethereum clients up into separate pieces.  I think this could yield some huge wins for the ecosystem.

author: guthl_starkware
content: <@456226577798135808>How so? It would be very useful for L2s

author: Deleted User
content: and one type of message that contains Transction hash

author: Deleted User
content: which was introduced recently

author: sky.cactus
content: I believe the transaction hash (as commonly known) is how devp2p figures out which transactions peers do/don't know about.

author: Deleted User
content: this new type of message that uses transaction hashes is called `NewPooledTransactionHashesMsg`

author: sky.cactus
content: Prior to that transaction hashes weren't actually part of consensus or the network layer at all?

author: Deleted User
content: and that's the first time in devp2p that transaction hashes are explicitely used

author: sky.cactus
content: Huh, interesting.

author: Deleted User
content: and it was only introduced in eth/65

author: sky.cactus
content: I always thought that transaction hashes were a core part of the protocol since the beginning.

author: sky.cactus
content: I didn't realize that it was just a "common convention used across clients for uniquely identifying transactions to tools/users".

author: guthl_starkware
content: It would allowed easy to analyse conditional transactions. Users could sign a conditional transaction based on the recorded of this txHash before being broadcasted and verify onchain that it was indeed included

author: sky.cactus
content: You can already prove that a transaction was included in the chain, it just is a bit expensive to do (requires a block proof and a transaction inclusion proof).

author: sky.cactus
content: There is quite a bit of resistance to allowing the EVM to access historic chain state directly because that works against light clients and stateless clients, which ideally don't store much of anything.

author: sky.cactus
content: Own `this` transaction hash being accessible from inside the EVM doesn't seem like it has any obvious drawbacks, but it does enshrine transaction hashes as part of the core protocol (which I learned just now isn't the case right now).

author: .vbuterin
content: > There is quite a bit of resistance to allowing the EVM to access historic chain state directly because that works against light clients and stateless clients, which ideally don't store much of anything.

author: .vbuterin
content: It's not just that, it's more that if the EVM could access historic state, then the history would become part of the state, and so all full nodes would have to be archive nodes

author: guthl_starkware
content: By making the txHash accessible within the EVM, you would let devs store only the interesting history and pay for it

author: guthl_starkware
content:
> which I learned just now isn't the case right now
<@!301186049323958275> That, I did not know

author: Deleted User
content: Making more things visible needs to be weighed very carefully. It is quite easy to add things in, but it is almost impossible to take them out when you realise it was a mistake

author: Deleted User
content: usually, the more things are visible from the EVM, the harder optimisations become

author: .vbuterin
content: The thing that we *can* do is do things to make it easier to Merkle-prove history (eg. EIP 2935) so you can do whatever history-dependent things you want with witnesses

author: sky.cactus
content:
Does anyone know what exactly this means (`BlockBodies (0x06)` devp2p message)?
> The items in the list are some of the blocks, minus the header, in the format described in the main Ethereum specification

author: sky.cactus
content:
```
[[transactions_0, uncles_0] , ...]
``` What is `transactions` here?

author: sky.cactus
content: On a similar vein, what is `transactionList` in `NewBlock`?  Is it a list of hashes, or a list of encoded transactions?

author: Deleted User
content: `BlockBodies` is a list of entities "BlockBody". Each of these entities consists of two parts - list of transactions, and list of uncle headers

author: Deleted User
content: Inside the `NewBlock` packet, you have two entities - "Block" and "TotalDifficulty"

author: Deleted User
content: "Block" entity consists of 3 sub-entities: "Header", list of transactions and list of uncle headers

author: Deleted User
content: in both cases, the list of transactions is an RLP list of RLP-encoded transaction entities

author: sky.cactus
content: Created EIP-2976 which defines the networking layer specification for Typed Transactions (2718).  While technically we can release these in separate hard forks, I suspect a network split would occur if we actually did in reality since a miner could include a transaction in a block (2718) that none of the clients would be able to gossip.

author: sky.cactus
content: So really, 2976 needs to go live *first*, and then 2718 I think (or at the same time, which is probably the easiest).

author: sky.cactus
content:
<@!273808422753796097> for 2930 (access lists), how do you feel about the following format?
```
0x02 || ssz(nonce, gasPrice, gasLimit, to, value, data, accessList) || ssz(yParity, r, s)
0x03 || ssz(nonce, gasPrice, gasLimit, to, value, data, chainId, accessList) || ssz(yParity, r, s)
```

author: sky.cactus
content: Note: `ssz(0x02, nonce, gasPrice, ...)` is the same as `0x02 || ssz(nonce, gasPrice, ...)`

author: sky.cactus
content: Note: `ssz(yParity, r, s)` is the same as `yParity || r || s`.

author: sky.cactus
content: It is worth noting that we cannot extract the signature without fully parsing the signed payload since we need to parse the payload to figure out how long the variable length data items is the transaction are first.

author: sky.cactus
content: However, unlike the current situation, we don't need to re-encode anything.  If we were to use RLP for the data, I think we could avoid parsing it since the full length of the signed data would be known by looking at the first byte(s), and then we could skip over the rest.

author: .vbuterin
content:
> 0x02 || ssz(nonce, gasPrice, gasLimit, to, value, data, accessList) || ssz(yParity, r, s)

That's the same as `ssz([0x02, [nonce, gasPrice, gasLimit, to, value, data, accessList], [yParity, r, s]])`, right?

author: .vbuterin
content: ah actually not quite, because `accessList` is variable length

author: sky.cactus
content: Yeah.

author: .vbuterin
content: hmm, maybe put the signature before?

author: .vbuterin
content: To maximize the number of things that are in known positions

author: sky.cactus
content: Then we would need to duplicate the transaction type inside the signed data payload to avoid having to rebuild the signed data from pieces.

author: .vbuterin
content: actually I think SSZ might do that automatically already....

author: sky.cactus
content:
```
0x02 || yParity || r || s || ssz(0x02, nonce, gasPrice, gasLimit, to, value, data, accessList)
```

author: sky.cactus
content: It duplicates the transaction type, but that is only one byte wasted and we gain the benefit of being able to validate the transaction without doing any decoding.

author: sky.cactus
content: Just pluck the signature from the beginning and validate that signature against the remaining bytes.

author: sky.cactus
content: While the data duplication annoys me, being able to validate the signature without decoding anything is *really* appealing to me, since we want signature validation to happen ASAP after receiving something to limit the effectiveness of DoS attacks.

author: .vbuterin
content: hmm but serialization/deserialization costs are pretty negligible, no?

author: sky.cactus
content: ðŸ¤·  Probably?

author: sky.cactus
content: 1 byte is also pretty negligible.  ðŸ™‚

author: sky.cactus
content: So it is epsilon vs epsilon.  ðŸ˜‰

author: sky.cactus
content: One nice thing is that it means that gossip can be done *without* actually knowing how to do SSZ decoding.

author: sky.cactus
content: This *could* be valuable in a gossip-only node in the network, which ties in to what <@456226577798135808> has been pushing for (splitting the client up into smaller modular parts).

author: sky.cactus
content: This, of course, assumes that such a gossip node doesn't validate the transaction is valid beyond just checking the signature, which wouldn't work with AA at all.

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm not super married to any of these ideas, I just want something better than what is currently in 2930 since we have tentatively all agreed on 2817 now, along with the potential of using SSZ instead of RLP for encoding of transactions.

author: Deleted User
content:
> This, of course, assumes that such a gossip node doesn't validate the transaction is valid beyond just checking the signature, which wouldn't work with AA at all.
<@!301186049323958275> My plan to make it mandatory for transactions to include witness to be able to circulate in this network, so that some basic anti-DOS validation can be done without having access to the Ethereum state

author: Deleted User
content: And that might be what would enable experimentations with AA transactions too

author: Deleted User
content: and I am not "pushing" for it ðŸ™‚ I am just planning to do it as some point, with some help, when we have other pieces of infrastructure in place

author: Deleted User
content: at this moment, there are some pieces missing, and whether I push or not, the situation won't change much. We are working towards it

author: Deleted User
content: my main strategy is to "pull", not to "push" ðŸ™‚
